article.headline: Miami (FL) 72, Massachusetts 71
article.story: AMHERST, Mass. (AP) -- Anthony Harris scored 33 points and Jack McClinton added 15 as Miami held on to beat Massachusetts 72-71 on Tuesday night. The Hurricanes (8-7) led by as many as eight points with 6:45 to play, but UMass (10-4) made it a two-point game, 70-68, on a basket by James Life with 1:21 left. Free throws by Dwayne Collins and Brian Asbury in the final minute proved the clinchers for Miami. UMass' Gary Forbes hit a 3-pointer at buzzer. Harris was 13-for-19 from the field, including four 3-pointers. Denis Clemente added 11 points for Miami. Rashaun Freeman and Forbes had 16 points apiece and Life added 14 points for UMass. Freeman led both teams with 10 rebounds. Stephane Lasme had 10 points and blocked seven shots for UMass. The Minutemen led 34-32 at halftime. A 14-2 run early in the first half gave UMass its first lead. Freeman had seven points in the spurt. Miami went back on top briefly at 30-29 on a 3-point basket by Clemente, but Etienne Brower retaliated with a hoop and UMass stayed on top for the rest of the half.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
